contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize that he obeyed Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: following the word of Yahweh, just as he was commanded to do

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: he was told to do by Yahweh's word, as Yahweh had commanded him

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: to his work, to his special tasks

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and may be combined to state that the offerings that someone gives belong to the priest to whom they have been given. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The offerings of every person will be for the priest; if anyone gives anything to the priest, it will belong to him

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize that he must obey the obligations of his vow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: he must keep the obligations ... to keep the promise indicated by the law for the Nazirite

contextId.information: These two phrases describe the same group of people two different ways. AT: "the leaders of Israel who are also the heads of their ancestors families" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: the leaders of Israel ... the heads of their ancestor's families

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasize the firstborn sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: each male child who opens the womb, the firstborn

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize that they needed to obey the commands. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: follow all the regulations, and obey all the decrees

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize that the stranger must obey all of the rules about the Passover. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: keeping the rules of the Passover, and obeying the laws for it

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize that God punished them immediately, even while they were eating the meat. AT: "While they were still eating the meat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: While the meat was still between their teeth, while they were chewing it

contextId.information: The phrase "against Moses" clarifies that he is the "servant" of whom Yahweh speaks. AT: "against my servant, Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: against my servant, against Moses

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: We will die here. We will all perish!

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. AT: "Every firstborn male" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Everything that opens the womb, all the firstborn

contextId.information: The two phrases refer to the same thing. Together they emphasize that the covenant will endure forever. AT: "an agreement forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: an everlasting covenant of salt ... a binding covenant forever

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He will remain unclean; his uncleanness will remain on him

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. They mean that it is time for Aaron to die and for his spirit to go to the place where his ancestors are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: must die and be gathered to his people

contextId.information: These are two names that refer to the same city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Heshbon ... city of Sihon

contextId.information: These two phrases refer to the same people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Moab ... people of Chemosh

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing, and emphasize how afraid Moab was. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Moab was very afraid of the people ... Moab was in terror of the people of Israel

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. They emphasize that Balak wants Balaam to curse the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: 'Come, curse Jacob for me,' ... 'Come, defy Israel.'

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. Balaam viewed Israel from the top of a hill. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: from the top of the rocks I see him ... from the hills I look at him

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. Possible meanings are 1) God has given Israel only good things or 2) there is no sin in Israel that would cause him to judge them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: hardship in Jacob ... trouble in Israel

contextId.information: These two lines mean the same thing, that no curse that anyone puts on the nation of Israel will be effective. Here "Jacob" is a metonymy that refers to Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: There is no sorcery that works against Jacob ... no fortune-telling harms Israel

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meaning, emphasizing how much God will bless them compared to other nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Their king is to be higher ... their kingdom will be honored

contextId.information: These two sentences have similar meanings and are combined to emphasize making a vow or promise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: When anyone makes a vow to Yahweh, or swears an oath

contextId.information: These two statements say basically the same thing and emphasize that she must keep all of her vows.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: then all her vows will remain in force. Every promise ... will remain in force

contextId.information: "the vow that she has made ... that is, the rash talk of her lips." These two phrases refer to the same thing. The second phrase describes the vow that the woman made. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: the vow that she has made ... the rash talk of her lips

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. This is a polite way to emphasize that it is time for Moses to die and for his spirit to go to the place where his ancestors are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: you will die and be gathered to your people
